titleStmt.title: To ANGUS FLETCHER,Angus Fletcher (1799-1862), sculptor. Born in Edinburgh; studied in London and Italy; exhibited 1831-9 at the Royal Academy, where his bust of CD was shown in 1839; subsequently abandoned sculpture and eventually settled in Italy: see Pilgrim Letters 1, p. 514, and later vols. The bust of CD is in the Charles Dickens House Museum. [?MARCH 1838-FEBRUARY 1839]

sourceDesc.p: MS Yale University Library. Date: CD was sitting to Pickering from early 1838 to c. Feb 1839 (below); if Kate’s portrait was that by Laurence (below), then after Aug 1838. Address: A Fletcher Esquire / Dean Street.

body.p: We find that to be dutiful and relation-like we must alter our plans, and ask divers aunts and uncles to dine with us to-day at 6. Will you alter your plan of coming in the evening, and dine with us too?

A most mean signature, but I am writing under the soothing influence of Mr. Pickering,Ferdinand Pickering, of 14 High Street, Camden Town, Active 1831-82; exhibited at the Royal Academy and elsewhere; painted mainly genre, literary, and historical subjects. His name and address noted in CD’s Diary, 10 Mar 38; sittings presumably began about then. The portrait (the “practical joke against me”) still in progress, 4 Jan 39 (To Forster, Pilgrim Letters 1, p. 491), and an appointment again noted in CD’s Diary, 21 Feb 39. No portrait of CD by him is known to exist. the author of that meek portrait still unfinished. A word in reply. Apropos. KateCatherine Dickens (1815-79), CD's wife. wants her pictureNot identified. Fletcher may have intended a companion bust of Kate to CD’s, using in part a sketch by himself or, possibly, an existing portrait. Samuel Laurence finished Kate’s portrait in Aug 1838 (Pilgrim Letters 1, p. 395 n.3) and Fletcher might even be working from that. (only for the day) if you can send it by bearer.
